review.title: Using the Crowd to Generate Content for Scenario-Based Serious-Games
review.abstract: In the last decade, scenario-based serious-games have become a main tool for learning new skills and capabilities. An important factor in the development of such systems is the overhead in time, cost and human resources to manually create the content for these scenarios. We focus on how to create content for scenarios in medical, military, commerce and gaming applications where maintaining the integrity and coherence of the content is integral for the system's success. To do so, we present an automatic method for generating content about everyday activities through combining computer science techniques with the crowd. We use the crowd in three basic ways: to capture a database of scenarios of everyday activities, to generate a database of likely replacements for specific events within that scenario, and to evaluate the resulting scenarios. We found that the generated scenarios were rated as reliable and consistent by the crowd when compared to the scenarios that were originally captured. We also compared the generated scenarios to those created by traditional planning techniques. We found that both methods were equally effective in generated reliable and consistent scenarios, yet the main advantages of our approach is that the content we generate is more varied and much easier to create. We have begun integrating this approach within a scenario-based training application for novice investigators within the law enforcement departments to improve their questioning skills.

sections.heading: EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: In this section, we present the evaluation of the generated revised scenarios and related descriptive activities. Note that we do not include the evaluation of the MaxSat Solver because we use a commercially available, previously investigated solver. We have evaluated the Activity Generator (KAR) and the Activity Details Generator (SNACS) separately, as described in the following sections. We use crowdsourcing to evaluate the effectiveness of our approach in a comprehensive user study (200 subjects), also in AMT, but with a different pool of employees. We ensure that the subjects answer truthfully by including open test questions and manually checking before accepting the grades. We also estimate that conducting a survey should take 8-15 minutes, so that we filtered out forms completed in less than 4 minutes. Examples of these questionnaires can be found at http: / / aimamt.azurewebsites.net /.

sections.heading: Activities Generation Evaluation
sections.text: The purpose of this experiment is to verify the integrity and coherence of the activities of the scenario list after the exchange of any of their activities.Setup We chose to use the daily schedules that we have already collected from the set for DSA as the original scenario (without the activity details that will be evaluated next).We randomly created a section of 7-8 hours from each of the original activities list to which we refer as the original. We then randomly selected an activity to be replaced for the list. We generated three revised lists by replacing the selected activity, two of the lists were created using KAR algorithms, one with K = 1 and the other with K = 11, which we refer to as KAR K = 1 and KAR K = 11. The third random list was generated with a random substitute and was implemented as a baseline to ensure the validity of the experiment.

sections.heading: Activity-Details Generation Evaluation
sections.text: The purpose of this experiment is to verify the authenticity, integrity and coherence of the generated descriptive activities that accompany the revised scenarios. Setup We decided to evaluate four types of activities: see-a-movie, eat-at-a-restaurant, buy-food and drycleaning. For each activity, we generated 4 user profiles. Each activity detail was associated with its user profile and the AMT workers were randomly selected 4 additional activity details for each activity type. As before, we conducted the experiment using AMT questionnaires. Each activity detail was associated with its user profile and the AMT workers were evaluated (with the same 6 value as before) six aspects of activity details for each activity type.

sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: The paper contains the following two key contributions: (i) This is the first paper to address the problem of modifying scenarios to generate personal information while maintaining consistency, even when generating different scenarios. (ii) It provides a methodology to use crowdsourcing in principle for this task. Instead of modifying scenarios manually, making the development process both time and resource intensive, we used the crowd as the source of our data set, thus reducing the effort required to maintain coherence in these scenarios. To accomplish this task, we use MaxSat's logical engine in combination with a novel approach to generating everyday scenarios using the crowd. Our review showed that our revised scenarios and the details of their activities were rated as reliable and consistent as the original scenarios and the details of the original activities, and also compared them with the details generated with the more expensive game engineering.
